label: Letter from Thomas S. Grimke to Reverend Louis Dwight, June 16, 1830
description: A letter (1831) of Thomas S. Grimke to Reverend Louis Dwight, Boston, replies to a printed questionnaire, giving his approval to the idea of abolishing imprisonment for debt.

Charleston,
16 June, 1830

Revd. and Dear Sir,

I received a good while since your letter of 19th
April, and certainly owe you an apology for that long delay
of my answer. I presume you have a Copy of the questions [illegible]
Wed in the Circular in the order in which they appear in
your previous letter. I have therefore numbered them, and my
answers will bear corresponding numbers.
1.2.3.4. If imprisonment—for debt it to form a [paeltry?] the ordi:
nary permanent-scheme of laws, as it now does, there ought o
be a limit-: and I know now so appropriate, as to deny to the
Creditor this privilege of imprisonment, under twenty-Dolls
that being the Sum fixed by the Constitution of the W.D. as
the limit above which a Citizen Cannot be deprived of trial
by Jury.
5.6. I do not think imprisonment for debt ought ever to be al-
lowed, in any Case after judgment, except on an affixable by
the less, or someone for him, of actual fraud or Concealment,
or of reason to believe it: nor would I suffer the [illegible]
to have his Execution without giving the Defendant an oppor-
tunity to answer or oath, subject to a personal examination
unless the Perp or some one for him would swear that he knew
or believed the Defendant would conceal himself or abscond,
or was then about to depart.

[End page 1]

7. I see no use in imprisonment at all under Ca Sa, unless fraud be al-
leged or believed: and know not any reason for the day prac-
tice, of which you appeal.

8. There can be but one answer, No Christian can do it with a clean
conscience. Nay more, he cannot imprison the infidel or the heathen.
This answers W.9

10. If there be no allegation or belief of proud, I can hardly [illegible]
the power to imprison for debt arbitrarily, as anything more
than personal tyranny, the relic of a [illegible], unjust rage, inca-
pable of estimating the value and dignity of personal rights,
The disproportion is erroneous.

11. I am satisfied no evils would result from abolishing im-
prisonment from debt, provided proper precautious be [illegible]
to protect the Creditor, and subject the unwilling or fraudulent
Debtor to the law of imprisonment—

12. I think the following would be [done?] of the advantage resul-
ting from the abolition of imprisonment for debt. 1. personal rights
would acquire a new value and a higher dignity. 2. In prison duty
for debt—would be confined to its proper object, err as a reasona:
:ble means adapted to the attainment of an important lawful end.
3. Imprisonment—for debt [instead of being regarded as in no res-
pect disgraceful, but-rather a misfortune] would that be regar-
ded as absolutely dishonorable and this would be a powerful
inducement to escape it. 4. To considerate Mean would subject a:

[End page 2]

nother to this ordeal; but under circumstances of just suspicion. 5. Im-
prisonment for debt would never be used, as it too often is, not for the
legitimate purpose of obtaining the Debtors properly; but to extort
money or security from friends or relations.

13. Never, that I remember; tho I really believe I have lost debts
which I might otherwise have recovered. My end would have been
attained, under a proper system.

14. My experience is that the Ca. Sa. has scarcely ever have been
of any avail; far, far less efficient, that a well conducted system
would make it. I have nothing further to add [illegible] this [illegible]
as a statement at large, of the scheme I should propose, would
be the best commentary or explanation of my [illegible] views.
I thank you for the volume of the P[illegible] Society, han-
ded to me by Mr. Jasper [Couring?]. Let me request your acceptance
in return of the address herewith, on the expediency and duty of
adopting the Bible as a Class Book through the whole Court of
education from the preliminary School to the University.

Yrs Respectfully
Thos. S. Grimke

The Revd. Louis Dwight
Boston

I have confused what I have said in answer to your en-
quiries, to the case of taking the body under the Ca:Sa: or final
process to couple payment of the debt, I think that the Creditor
should have the privilege, not the common right as in the Case
of arresting the Defendant or bail process, to Complete security

[End page 3]

 for the debt, I would abolish the general right but would al-
low the creditor to employ this process [illegible], in addition to
the Customary affidavit of the debt, he would add an oath either
that the debt was insecured in his belief or that the Defendant
was about to quit the State, or alleging feud or Concealment,
or unfairness in the Contracting of the debt

My experience and [illegible], after twenty years prac-
tice are that in Mine out of Few cases, and I am not sure, but
that I might say, in nineteen out of twenty the property as-
signed now so [illegible] or of such doubtful Character that
no one would act as Assignee.

-1830
Louis Dwight
-[Cellum?]

[End page 4]
